bibl.title: Transcript of letter from Walter Reed to Simon Flexner, November 3, 1902.

div1.p: Reed turns down an invitation to speak at Flexner's Pathological Society in Philadelphia.

div1.head: Transcript of letter from Walter Reed to Simon Flexner, November 3, 1902.
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Copy.
War Department,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, Nov. 3, 1902.
My dear Flexner,
div1.p:
So you were responsible for that troublesome invitation to come
to Philadelphia? Dear me! What ever put such a foolish notion in your otherwise
beautifully balanced cranium? “Follow in the footsteps of Drs. Welch, Councilman,
Hektoen and some other worthies?” My good friend, what strange madness has taken
hold of you? Why, those “worthies” had something worth talking about! What
have I? You certainly can't mean that I should impose upon an unsuspecting audience
yellow fever? Why the very thought causes the cold creeps to chase each other
adown my spinal column! I simply couldn't do it! I have hardly given the sub-
ject a thought for the past year: on the contrary, I have had during that time
nothing but hum-drum, every day military duties to perform, which, from their very
monotony, have almost reduced me to a condition of hopeless idiocy! Now, upon the
death of Dr. Merrilel, I take up the duties of Librarian of the S. G.'s library, and
shall get more and more out of touch with practical work. Seriously, your patho-
logical society, if it searched the land through, couldn's find so lame a duck as
your humble servant, for an annual address. Over and above this, I have the great-
est distaste of appearing before an audience, and each time vow that I will never
yield again. Regretting that I could not comply with the kind invitation of your
society, and with ever so much love, believe me, as always, my dear Flexner,
